Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: enPour - an Assistive Pouring Device for Enhanced Control and Minimized Effort
Award.AbstractNarration:
In the United States, an estimated 52.5 million adults have doctor-diagnosed arthritis, and 22.7 million report limitations due to their arthritis. In addition, the market landscape of assistive devices for seniors is growing. According to the Transparency Market Research Group, this market is expected to reach an estimated value of almost $20 billion by 2019. Seniors with Arthritis suffer muscle deterioration over time, have pains, aches, stiffness, and swelling in or around the joints, as well as many other afflictions that effect motor skills and strength. For them the process of pouring out liquid from heavy containers such as milk jugs, water pitchers or large bowls can cause fatigue, pain and even physical harm by causing damage to joints in the fingers and hands. The proposed project 'enPour' will target individuals who suffer from disabilities which hinder their daily activities, independence, or quality of life. enPour is a superior solution that is intuitive, easy to use, and adaptable for a wide range of container sizes and shapes which sets it greatly apart from anything that is currently on the market.

enPour has been developed, and validated through rounds of prototype testing. An evidence of market interest for this product has been established and recognized through focus group studies conducted with the Houston local office of Arthritis Foundation. Through NSF I-Corps program, this team will conduct a nation-wide consumer research under the guidance of I-Corps instructors. Through this training, the team's rimary goals can be summarized as: 1) identify and expand the core customer segments and the key value propositions of enPour, 2) attract third party investment and partners through product testing and demonstration, and 3) connect and establish a partnering relationship with a number of specialized healthcare institutions through the team's connections. The methods will primarily include onsite interviews, survey, prototype testing and demonstration. The I-Corps program will be a stepping stone for the team to gain an in-depth understanding of the targeted consumers, market and the potential sales channels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project “enPour - an Assistive Pouring Device for Enhanced Control and Minimized Effort” was carried out as planned with promising results. The project under the I-Corps awarding period includes two phases as reported below.

 

Phase I. Entrepreneurship Training through Discovery Research

Our target customers were people with arthritis, seniors over age 65. Through more than 150 interviews with customers, healthcare specialists and doctors across the US about our customers’ daily living, specific issues, challenges, and needs have been identified and prioritized. These issues seriously affect their daily activities and compromise their quality of life. Key issues are in a priority order:

  • Physical deficiencies: dexterity, strength, range of motion, mobility and etc.
  • Flare-ups and pain.
  • Emotional and mental stress affecting their disease and health condition.

 

Due to the disparity between the user’s ability and the input requirement that the device demands, one size fits all do not work in most assistive device design for our customers. Case studies revealed that many assistive devices in self-care, functional mobility, fall prevention, and food preparation remain under-addressed, do not work for our customers. These issues transcend a variety of medical complications, including but not limited to arthritis, multiple sclerosis, age-related disabilities, and veterans with combat-related injuries. High adaptability in physical operation and controls is necessary for assistive products to serve the majority of our customers.

 

Phase II. Development of a Power-assisted Platform for Applications

Based on findings of our research, we refocus on one of the most prominent issues in our customers’ physical deficiencies: reaching and getting objects around them, especially above their shoulder level or below their waist lever. This issue is significant due to affecting many activities in our customers’ daily living and causing injuries. Our study shows basic mechanical solutions do not work for customers with severe arthritis or other physical disabilities. Our team has initiated an exploration of utilizing the power of a pneumatic or a hydraulic actuator to help the users’ physical actions and movements. Multiple functional prototypes were developed to transform the motion of a hydraulic/pneumatic actuator into specific actions in applications. A platform model of a power assisted hydraulic/pneumatic system has been established. This platform provides a deep understanding of physical limitation and capability of our customers. With the superior functionality and minimized effort in use, this platform has a potential to disrupt the current assistive device market with a whole new set of power assisted devices.

 

A provisional patent has been filed for this platform technology. Our team is in the phase of further development. This new platform will shine a light in the micro power actuator application in compact assistive devices for individuals. Currently, there is no such a power-assisted system applied in daily use simple products. This includes reaching devices, bottle openers, walking canes and other small products. With the advancement of compact power modules, there is potential to apply them to small devices. This is a new attempt in assistive device design.

 

The potential broader impact of this project lies in two aspects:

  1. Applications of a power-assisted platform

This power-assisted platform has a potential for a range of applications in assistive devices to help people with disabilities. These applications will dramatically enhance the products’ performance and improve the users’ quality of life by empowering and enabling them to conduct many ADLs independently.

  1. A stage-specific design process in assistive technology/device design

One size fits all do not work for people with disabilities. This project demonstrates a stage-specific design approach in developing products for people with disabilities. Based on the stage of users’ physical condition, the device is developed accordingly. A high level of customization process ensures the functional effectiveness and ergonomics of devices to the end user. This process will enlighten the design and engineering community to develop better products for people with disabilities.
